title: How to ask a Why Question
text:
Slide here
Some code
library(ggdag)
library(dplyr)

coords <- read.table(header = TRUE, text = "
  x y name
  0 1 U
  1 0 L0
  2 0 A0
  3 0 Y0
  4 0 A1
  5 0 Y2
")

d <- dagify(
  A1 ~ L0 + A0,
  L0 ~ U,
  Y0 ~ U,
  Y2 ~ A1,
  Y2 ~ U + Y0,
  coords = coords)

ggdag(d) +
   theme_dag()

title: How to ask a Why Question
Asking questions in cross-cultural psychology
text:
test dag
install.packages(c("coda","mvtnorm","devtools","loo","dagitty","shape"))
devtools::install_github("rmcelreath/rethinking")
library(rethinking)
drawdag(d, arrow = "gray",  Z=list("U"))

title: Psych 434: Conducting Research Across Cultures
text:
Course Description
The official description:
This course will focus on theoretical and practical challenges for conducting research involving individuals from more than one cultural background or ethnicity. Topics are likely to include defining and measuring culture; developing culture-sensitive studies, choice of language and translation; communication styles and bias; questionnaire and interview design; qualitative and quantitative data analysis for cultural and cross-cultural research; minorities, power and ethics in cross-cultural research; and ethno-methodologies and indigenous research methodologies. Appropriate background for this course: PSYC 338.

title: Psych 434: Conducting Research Across Cultures
text:
Learning objectives
This course is an introduction to conducting research in cross-cultural psychology. Our goal is to provide you with the tools you will need to ask, and answer, psychological questions about culture.

title: Psych 434: Conducting Research Across Cultures
text:
Course learning objectives
This course is an introduction to conducting research in cross-cultural psychology. Our goal is to provide you with the tools and concepts you will need to conduct cross-cultural research.
The primary focus of this course is to develop your skills for collecting, analysing, and interpreting cultural data. By the end of the course, you will be prepared to contribute to cross-cultural research projects. While some of you may not pursue cross-cultural research in the future, the training you will receive will be invaluable for a wide range of tasks you may face as you navigate the complexities of cultural diversity in your personal and professional lives.
Foremost among these skills is ethical reasoning. Beginning in week 1, we will explore questions that are typically reserved for philosophy courses but are central to the conduct of psychology: why do we need to think about right and wrong in science? What if different people have different ideas about what is right and wrong in science? Is there hope for ethical progress? Can science play a role in ethical progress? We will provide you with a set of strategies for addressing these questions.
Again, the primary focus of this course is impart analytical skills that are essential for conducting cross-cultural research. Beginning in week 2, we will teach you the basics of programming in the statistical language R. The past several decades have brought extraordinary new tools to psychological scientists, many of which require literacy in computer programming. While some of you may find the thought of programming thrilling, others may find it terrifying or boring! We promise that programming can be fun. This course is designed to help you find that joy.
At the heart of cultural research are problems of interpretation. Beginning in week 3 the course will turn its focus to developing skills for constructing and validating measures in cross-cultural research. Again these skills will be invaluable for a wide range of tasks you may face in psychological science and will help you to address problems that will arise in other areas of your research and work. Measurement will occupy our attention through week 6.
Causal inference is a holy grail of all psychological research. Beginning in week 7 and for the following four weeks, the course will impart skills that you require to disentangle causation from correlation. Again our focus will be on the special problems that arise for cultural datasets. Notably, in psychological science, causal inference remains underdeveloped, and the material in this part of the course will position you to make potentially important contributions, whether or not your interests lie in cross-cultural psychology.
In the final two seminars, we will return to considerations of ethics and ownership in cross-cultural research, and look ahead to future directions. The practice sessions in these seminars will be devoted to helping students with their projects.

title: Preliminaries
text:
Class Participation


your willingness to ask/answer questions and generally contribute to class discussion; and


the quality of your contributions

title: Preliminaries
text:
Take Home Research Concepts Workbook

This test will help you revise core statistical and methodological issues. It is a chance to brush up on basic statistical knowledge and will help you re-familiarize yourself with material that we will build on later in this course.
The key focus is the revision of basic terms, including correlation, regression, and on basic R applications.
The test contains a theoretical and a practical component. Therefore, it is essential that you complete these questions since you will need to understand the material for the more advanced techniques and approaches that we cover in this course.
There is no word limit (be reasonable)
You can use any source that you find useful.
Artificially Intelligence Chatbots mau be used but they occasionally make errors – sometimes spectacular errors. Currently they make these errors confidently
Generally, it is better practice, at least for now, to use peer-reviewed publications.
Whatever resourcse you use must be cited. Failure to cite your source is a form of academic misconduct.
You may complete the test in your own study time. We ask that you work individually.

title: How to ask a Why Question
text:
Dags

library(ggdag)


Attaching package: 'ggdag'


The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    filter

library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

coords <- read.table(header = TRUE, text = "
  x y name
  0 1 U
  1 .1 L0
  2 0 A0
  3 0.1 Y0
  4 0 A1
  5 0.2 Y2
")

d <- dagify(
  A0 ~ L0,
  A1 ~ A0,
  L0 ~ U,
  Y0 ~ A0,
  Y2 ~ A1 + L0,
  Y2 ~ U + Y0,
  coords = coords)

ggdag(d) +
   theme_dag()

title: How to ask a Why Question
text:
DAG

library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

# coordinates for graph
coords <- read.table(header = TRUE, text = "
  x y name
  0 -1 U
  0 1 L
  2 0 A0
  3 0 Y0
  4 0 A1
  6 0 Y2
")

# make into daggity object
d <- dagify(
  L ~ U,
  A0 ~  L + U,
  Y0 ~  L + U,
  A1 ~  L + U ,
  Y2 ~  L + U,
  exposure = "A1",
  outcome = "Y2",
  latent = "U",
  coords = coords)

# plot
ggdag(d,  text = TRUE, node = FALSE, 
      text_size = 9,
      text_col = "black") +
   theme_dag()

title: How to ask a Why Question
text:
Check confounding

ggdag_adjustment_set(d) + theme_dag_blank()

Warning in dag_adjustment_sets(., exposure = exposure, outcome = outcome, : Failed to close backdoor paths. Common reasons include:
            * graph is not acyclic
            * backdoor paths are not closeable with given set of variables
            * necessary variables are unmeasured (latent)

title: How to ask a Why Question
text:
Visualise confounding

ggdag_dseparated(d,
  controlling_for = c("L", "A0", "Y0"),
  text = TRUE, collider_lines = FALSE
) + theme_dag()
